desc: Puerto Rican nationalists attempt to assassinate Harry S. Truman at Blair House.
Senator Joseph McCarthy claims to have a list of 205 communists in the State Department during a speech in Wheeling, West Virginia.
President Truman relieves General Douglas MacArthur of his command in Korea.
The EBR-I in Idaho becomes the first nuclear reactor to generate usable electricity.
The first hydrogen bomb, 'Ivy Mike,' is detonated in the Marshall Islands.
The keel of the USS Nautilus, the world's first nuclear-powered submarine, is laid.
The Korean Armistice Agreement is signed at Panmunjom.
Operation Ajax: A CIA-backed coup overthrows Iranian Prime Minister Mohammad Mossadegh.
The Army-McCarthy hearings are televised, leading to the downfall of Senator McCarthy.
The USS Nautilus is commissioned as the first nuclear-powered ship.
The Montgomery Bus Boycott begins following the arrest of Rosa Parks.
The Geneva Summit begins, the first meeting of Big Four leaders since WWII.
President Eisenhower signs the Federal Aid Highway Act, creating the Interstate System.
Nikita Khrushchev delivers his 'Secret Speech' denouncing Stalin's cult of personality.
Eisenhower sends federal troops to Little Rock to enforce school integration.
The Vanguard TV3 satellite launch fails, exploding on the pad in public view.
Explorer 1, the first U.S. satellite, successfully reaches orbit.
Operation Blue Bat: U.S. Marines land in Lebanon to support the Chamoun government.
Hawaii is admitted as the 50th U.S. State.
The 'Kitchen Debate' takes place between Nixon and Khrushchev in Moscow.
A U.S. U-2 spy plane piloted by Francis Gary Powers is shot down over the USSR.
The Greensboro sit-ins begin at a Woolworth's lunch counter.
In his farewell address, President Eisenhower warns of the 'Military-Industrial Complex.'
JFK addresses Congress, setting the goal of landing a man on the moon by 1970.
James Meredith becomes the first Black student at the University of Mississippi after riots.
Starfish Prime: The U.S. detonates a high-altitude nuclear weapon in space.
Civil rights activist Medgar Evers is assassinated in Jackson, Mississippi.
The USS Thresher nuclear submarine sinks during deep-dive tests, killing all aboard.
Congress passes the Gulf of Tonkin Resolution, escalating U.S. involvement in Vietnam.
The first Surgeon General's report on the health risks of smoking is released.
'Bloody Sunday': Civil rights marchers are attacked on the Edmund Pettus Bridge.
The Great Northeast Blackout leaves 30 million people without power.
The first episode of 'Star Trek' premieres on NBC.
The Black Panther Party is founded by Huey Newton and Bobby Seale.
Loving v. Virginia: The Supreme Court strikes down bans on interracial marriage.
The Apollo 1 fire kills astronauts Grissom, White, and Chaffee during a test.
Riots erupt outside the Democratic National Convention in Chicago.
The USS Pueblo is seized by North Korean forces.
The Woodstock Music & Art Fair takes place in Bethel, New York.
The Stonewall Riots begin in Greenwich Village, sparking the modern LGBTQ+ rights movement.
The Kent State shootings occur as National Guardsmen fire on anti-war protesters.
Nixon signs the Public Health Cigarette Smoking Act, banning TV tobacco ads.
The New York Times begins publishing excerpts from the Pentagon Papers.
The 'Nixon Shock': The U.S. unilaterally ends the direct convertibility of dollars to gold.
President Nixon arrives in Beijing for a historic week-long visit to China.
Alabama Governor George Wallace is shot and paralyzed during a campaign stop.
OPEC begins an oil embargo against the U.S. in response to support for Israel.
The 'Saturday Night Massacre': Nixon fires special prosecutor Archibald Cox.
President Gerald Ford grants a full pardon to Richard Nixon.
Patty Hearst is kidnapped by the Symbionese Liberation Army.
The Apollo-Soyuz Test Project sees U.S. and Soviet spacecraft dock in orbit.
President Ford survives two separate assassination attempts within three weeks.
The Viking 1 lander becomes the first U.S. spacecraft to land safely on Mars.
Apple Computer is formed by Steve Jobs, Steve Wozniak, and Ronald Wayne.
President Jimmy Carter pardons most Vietnam War draft evaders.
A major blackout and subsequent looting occur in New York City.
Harvey Milk and Mayor George Moscone are assassinated in San Francisco.
The U.S. Senate votes to gradually turn over control of the Panama Canal.
Iranian students seize the U.S. Embassy in Tehran, taking 52 hostages.
The Soviet Union invades Afghanistan to prop up the communist government.
'Miracle on Ice': The U.S. Olympic hockey team defeats the Soviet Union.
CNN (Cable News Network) launches as the first 24-hour news channel.
Sandra Day O'Connor is nominated as the first female Supreme Court Justice.
The CDC reports the first cases of what would later be known as AIDS.
The Vietnam Veterans Memorial is dedicated in Washington, D.C.
The first Tylenol poisonings occur in Chicago, causing seven deaths.
U.S. forces invade Grenada in Operation Urgent Fury.
Stanislav Petrov correctly identifies a Soviet early-warning system error, preventing nuclear war.
The Summer Olympics open in Los Angeles, boycotted by the Soviet bloc.
Ronald Reagan's 'we begin bombing in five minutes' microphone gaffe occurs.
Live Aid concerts are held simultaneously in London and Philadelphia.
The Achille Lauro cruise ship is hijacked by members of the PLF.
The Iran-Contra affair begins to break in a Lebanese magazine.
The 'Quemada' case: U.S. resident Rodrigo Rojas is burned alive by Chilean soldiers.
Black Monday: The Dow Jones Industrial Average drops 22.6% in one day.
The USS Stark is hit by two Exocet missiles from an Iraqi jet, killing 37.
The USS Vincennes shoots down Iran Air Flight 655, killing all 290 aboard.
The Morris Worm, the first major internet worm, is released.
The Tiananmen Square protests in Beijing end in a military crackdown.
The U.S. invades Panama (Operation Just Cause) to depose Manuel Noriega.
